meeting_annotations.speaker: WB
meeting_annotations.transcript: In certain basic cases, people are performing experiments.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: A document is shared on the screen. The document appears to be an agenda or meeting notes. No changes are made to the document in this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: RA
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think that problem is true across academia in general because you're talking about a catalyst that in industry will be three-dimensional and you can't access the outer surface anymore. You've got to do it computationally or by some bulk method. Rebecca, is that something that your computational work has touched on?
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: Same document as before. No changes are made to the document in this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: RG
meeting_annotations.transcript: Not that specific spectroscopy. I've done a lot of modeling related to surface enhanced Raman where you have the plasmonic type enhancements. But of course, surface enhanced Raman, tip enhanced Raman type things, you're limited by sticking some sort of metal tip or something in there. I also did want to loop back to Gary's point about the catalysts that are easier to measure, not necessarily being the best ones. From the computational side, I don't see that as necessarily being a problem because if we have somewhere where we can validate our methods and figure out what features do need to be included and don't need to be included, even if it's not the best catalyst, then that's still really valuable for us.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: Same document as before. No changes are made to the document in this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: GM
meeting_annotations.transcript: I agree. I think my comment was more in terms of in operando physical measurements where the lifetime of some intermediate becomes important, just being mapped onto the time scale of your measurement technique. But yeah, for computational approaches, that's the real beauty of it, I guess.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: Same document as before. No changes are made to the document in this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: RG
meeting_annotations.transcript: Just having the data to say, well, if we can match this catalyst that's mediocre, then hopefully similar methods will apply to catalysts that are.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: Same document as before. No changes are made to the document in this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: GM
meeting_annotations.transcript: Absolutely.
meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: Same document as before. No changes are made to the document in this segment.

meeting_annotations.screenshare_content: Same document as before. No changes are made to the document in this segment.

meeting_annotations.speaker: CM
meeting_annotations.transcript: Is that is that time? I mean, because we we can measure product distributions and then we know that many of the cells that we use for spectroscopy actually they do not have the same mass transfer property. Then you will see unless you are able to do both things at the same time, spectroscopy and product detection, it's very difficult to relate the activity and selectivity of one catalyst that we see in a reactor to what you see in during the spectroscopy analysis. So it's challenging but I see obviously people working on these efforts and yeah, it's a challenge.
